answers.explanation:
The OCT macula images demonstrate loss of the neurosensory retinal layers at the fovea leading to a central retinal thickness (red arrow). There is no hypo-reflective area underneath the retina suggestive of subretinal fluid and the inner retinal layers are within normal limits. There are central posterior hyper-reflective deposits at the level of the RPE, but these do not represent drusen.

![](/content/media/paed_4_3.webp)

answers.answerText: C. Disorganization of inner retinal layers

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What is the main finding in the OCT macula images above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
Fundus autofluorescence images were also conducted and are shown below:

![](/content/media/paed_4_4.webp)

Based on the fundus photos, OCT, and fundus autofluorescence images, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
Stargardt’s disease is the most common inherited macular dystrophy presenting with progressive vision loss in children and young adults. Patients typically complain of central visual loss, colour vision deficits and photophobia. The common signs on examination include a “beaten-bronze” appearance of the macula (blue arrow), foveal atrophy seen in question 1, or pisiform flecks (which are yellow-coloured accumulations of lipofuscin in the RPE).

Characteristically on autofluorescence, patients show hyper-autofluorescence of the posterior pole, sparing of the peripapillary area (green arrow) and hypo-autofluorescence at the fovea reflecting the atrophy (red arrow). Though there are no “pisiform flecks” seen in our patient, the diagnosis of Stargardt’s disease does not require the presence of flecks, but there is usually hyper-autofluorescence of the RPE.

![](/content/media/paed_4_5.webp)

References:

Tanna P, Strauss RW, Fujinami K, Michaelides M. Stargardt disease: clinical features, molecular genetics, animal models and therapeutic options. Br J Ophthalmol. 2017;101(1):25-30.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What gene is implicated in typical Stargardt’s disease?

answers.explanation:
Stargardt’s disease is typically an autosomal recessive condition caused by mutations in the ABCA4 gene, which is why most patients do not have a family history of eye disease (as seen in this patient). The ABCA4 gene maps to the short arm of chromosome 1 and codes for an ATP-binding cassette on photoreceptor disc membranes and is crucial in the recycling of 11-cis-retinal during the phototranduction cycle. ABCA4 mutations lead to progressive accumulation of di-retinoid-pyridinium-ethanolamine (vitamin A dimer) waste product, and ultimately lipofuscin, in the RPE causing hyperfluorescence of the posterior pole (sparing the peripapillary area).

References:

Glazer LC, Dryja TP. Understanding the etiology of Stargardt's disease. Ophthalmol Clin North Am. 2002 Mar;15(1):93-100
